content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a list of daily temperature data `temps` (numbers). Write a function `weather_data_analyzer` that performs statistical analyses on this data (use `Statistics` package). The function should return results in named tuple (construct it with `(; key1=value1,key2=value2)` syntax) containing the `average`, `max`, `min` temperatures, and a `trend` (can be only: `:increasing`, `:decreasing`, or `:stable`). If the list is empty, the function should return a named tuple with all values set to `nothing`.

function weather_data_analyzer(temps::Vector{Float64})::NamedTuple{(:average, :max, :min, :trend), T} where {T<:Union{Nothing, Float64}}
    if isempty(temps)
        return (; average = nothing, max = nothing, min = nothing, trend = nothing)
    end

    mean_temp = mean(temps)
    max_temp = maximum(temps)
    min_temp = minimum(temps)
    std_dev = std(temps)

    # Trend analysis (simple method: look at the last two values)
    if length(temps) < 2  # Not enough data to determine a trend
        trend = nothing
    elseif temps[end] > temps[end - 1]  # Increasing
        trend = :increasing
    elseif temps[end] < temps[end - 1]  # Decreasing
        trend = :decreasing
    else  # Stable (no change between the last two values)
        trend = :stable
    end

    return (; average = mean_temp, max = max_temp, min = min_temp, trend = trend)
end

# Example usage:
temps = [20, 21, 23, 25, 27]  # Daily temperatures
result = weather_data_analyzer(temps)
println("Average temperature: ", result.average)
println("Maximum temperature: ", result.max)
println("Minimum temperature: ", result.min)
println("Temperature trend: ", result.trend)
